Letter from

to Maria Edgeworth , , August 23, 1816

div.p:
Will you permit me to address you, conscious as
I am that I have neglected the advantage & the honour of that
intercourse by letter which my heart all the while acknowledged in
its fullest extent. What an excellent & what a cruel piece is your
To Morrow ! How you could enter so well into feelings which your
activity & strength of mind must have hindered you from partaking
I cannot imagine, but to me it has given many a twinge of
conscience, & most particularly in the affair of letter writing which, if
I have happenned to delay a little too long, always becomes difficult to me
beyond imagination. Days pass, & the more honour & esteem I have for my
correspondent, the more I feel that I have nothing worth communicating
& my brain feels dry, - "as the remaining biscuit -
after a voyage". With regard to yourself, tho though longing to write, I
doubt if I should have had the courage, but for a hint communi-
cated by Mrs Baillie intimating that I might have taken amiss not
seeing more of you when you were in London . Oh my dear Miss Edgeworth, I cannot
bear you should think so for a moment. Much as I value
your
your society, I well know the demands on your time, I know the
homage paid you & I exulted in it for your sake & for my sex's
sake - And now will you forgive me? Will you now receive all the
acknowledgements I owe you, both in common with all those who have
been delighted & instructed by your charming works, & more particularly
as having received them from your hands. Long may you continue
to delight the world with livelier wit & humour than those who write
merely for amusement, & with juster & more impressive sentiments of
morality than most of those who write merely for instruction -

I should ask you if could resist the general spirit of migration & stay
at home when England is pouring itself over the continent, if I did
not hear, & very sorry I am to hear it, that Mr Edgeworth's state of health
is such as must prevent your leaving him. I tremble to think what tours
must be preparing for the press, what sweeping characters of nations will be
given by the traveller who has dined two or three times at a table d'hôte,
& how after we shall be sick between Dover & Calais - I am wishing to
lay a tax on English Absentees, not the tourist of a few months, but the
Nobleman who dismisses his servants, shuts up his mansion, & spends his vast
rents abroad - Pray have you had any Summer in Ireland? We have
not. A weeping, chilling, hope disappointing summer, if we must call
it such, but that it might not entirely want energy, we have
had
had, it seems, an earthquake in Scotland - A Summer without heat
is like a youth without affections, there is nothing to cheer the damp
& dreary season which succeeds it. I have myself felt much want of
some enlivening influence to counteract the languor of age & the
dreainess of a solitary house. Writing any any thing I have not
felt equal to, & reading has at times been a task to me, but at present
I feel better. Everyone here has not been so idle, Perhaps you have
seen my Brother's
Annals & tho though necessarily somewhat dry from the
necessary compression of such an eventful period, I think you will have
been pleased with the fairness & impartiality with which they are
written. My neice, Miss Aikin, has made some progress in
Memoirs of the reign of Elizabeth . She is taking great pains with
it & I hope it will answer her expectation & her friends' - We are
expecting every day another Canto of Child Harold , but I apprehend the
Author has lost too much of the public favour by his late cruel behaviour to
his wife to be as popular as he has been. I have now upon my table the
strangest Poem - Wilson's
City of the Plague , a heap of horrors natural &
moral - and Lee Hunt's Rimini , the most fantastic. Thus it is when
the natural & easy has become a beaten path & the intellectual taste
wants excitement, as the sensitive by more pungent relishes the originally
disagreeable - My dear Madam have I not tired you? Will
you forgive me? Will you love me, little as I may deserve it
will
Will you convey my respectful Compliments to Mr & Mrs Edgeworth
& best wishes for all your family, & will you believe me with
the highest esteem & most affectionate good wishes,
I beg you to believe that I have written this
upon the knees of my heart
div.closer:
Your ever obliged
A L Barbauld
